newsitem.title: POLAND: Shy Polish poet apprehensive after Nobel prize.
newsitem.headline: Shy Polish poet apprehensive after Nobel prize.

text.p: Polish poet Wislawa Szymborska, winner of this year's Nobel Literature Prize, said on Thursday she was delighted but also apprehensive at the prospect of worldwide fame.

"This is a difficult situation. I am normally a very private person and now I forsee some difficult moments," Szymborska, 73, laughing with excitement, told Reuters by telephone from a hotel for writers in the mountain resort of Zakopane.
"I am very pleased for Polish literature although there are other poets like me in Poland...Tadeusz Rozewicz and Zbigniew Herbert to mention only two," she said.
She said that although she had been mentioned among the candidates, her selection by the Swedish academy -- which carries a $1.12 million award, had come as a surprise.
Szymborska paid warm tribute to Anders Bodegard, Swedish translator of her poems, which the academy recognised were hard to translate due to their stylistic variety.
"If this had been a mediocre translator we would not be talking today," she said.
Asked whether she would now appear more in public and perhaps give lectures abroad, the slight, grey-haired poet said she might be willing to travel but commented: "No, I never give lectures."
Earlier this week Szymborska won the Polish PEN club's poetry award and Polish literary critics were overjoyed at the literature award, the fourth to go to a Pole.
Respected Polish novelist Stanislaw Lem, who like Szymborska lives in the southern city of Krakow, told PAP news agency: "Wiska simply deserved this prize."
The science fiction author pointed out that poet Czeslaw Milosz had won the 1980 literature prize, adding that this showed Poland's poetry was greater than its prose.
The award to Szymborska surprised international observers, who had expected a novelist to win this year after Irish poet Seamus Heaney took last year's prize.
The Swedish academy said Szymborska won the prize for "poetry that with ironic precision allows the historical and biological context to come to light in fragments of human reality."
